items.title: Why I care about state-space models for EEG
items.imgAlt: State-space models blog post placeholder image
items.summary: A quick note on using HLDS and related models to capture structure in EEG, instead of treating everything as i.i.d. features.
items.content: EEG is genuinely dynamical. Modeling temporal structure explicitly helps with debugging, interpretability, and downstream decisions about what is learnable versus what is artifact.

items.title: Building an EEG/EMG helmet from scratch
items.imgAlt: EEG/EMG helmet blog post placeholder image
items.summary: Lessons from turning a modular acquisition concept into a real device that must deal with cables, noise, and human constraints.
items.content: Most of the work is not the final classifier. The hard parts are the physical system: electrode contact, EMI, grounding, synchronization, and usability. Those constraints dictate what modeling is feasible.

items.title: Teaching analysis and ML with Jupyter at UF
items.imgAlt: Teaching with Jupyter blog post placeholder image
items.summary: How IEEE SPS @ UF and UF AI Club pushed me to build a curriculum that connects analysis, probability, and ML in concrete ways.
items.content: Students often treat Real Analysis and Probability as disconnected from ML. A workshop-first format makes the motivation and the ‘why this theorem matters’ feel operational rather than abstract.
